title: Obama invites suspended Muslim teen to the White House | TheHill
text:
September 16, 2015, 01:29 pm Obama invites suspended Muslim teen to the White House By Mark Hensch 
President Obama on Wednesday extended a White House invitation to the Muslim ninth-grader who was suspended earlier this week for bringing a homemade clock to his Texas school. 
“Cool clock, Ahmed,” Obama tweeted about Ahmed Mohamed, 14. “Want to bring it to the White House?” ADVERTISEMENT “We should inspire more kids like you to like science,” the president added. “It’s what makes America great.”
Police in Irving, Texas announced on Wednesday that they are not filing charges against Mohamed after the Sudanese-American student brought his clock to MacArthur High School, NBC News reported. 
Mohamed was suspended for three days by Irving School District administrators after his clock went off during class. A teacher questioned whether the clock was a bomb and confiscated it. 
The student was later handcuffed and taken into police headquarters for questioning, according to NBC Dallas-Fort Worth . 
Reports emerged on Tuesday that Mohammed is an avid tinkerer who also builds his own radios and repairs go-karts. His family argues the incident is a result of anti-Muslim sentiment in Irving’s schools and law enforcement agencies. 
“He just wants to invent good things for mankind,” said the boy’s father, Mohamed Elhassan Mohamed, a Sudanese immigrant. 
“But because his name is Mohammed and because of Sept. 11, I think my son got mistreated,” he added, citing the 14 th anniversary last weekend of the terrorist attacks. 
Ahmed Mohamed’s suspension is drawing outrage on social media via the hashtag #StandwithAhmed. 
Democrat Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign tweeted its solidarity with the Texas student on Wednesday morning. 
“Assumptions and fears don’t keep us safe – they hold us back,” they wrote . “Ahmed, stay curious and keep building.” 
Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) also expressed support for the teenager. 
“Keep making #IStandWithAhmed,” he tweeted . “The world needs creative, innovative & brave people like you.” 
The Dallas Morning News reported that Ahmed Mohamed remains suspended and has vowed to never build mechanical devices again.
